coredata.dc:title: Polyurethane/LLZTO solid electrolyte with excellent mechanical strength and electrochemical property for advanced lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Gao, Yunqi
Wang, Chengliang
Wang, Hairui
Feng, Changhao
Pan, Hongwei
Zhang, Zhenpeng
He, Jianjiang
Wang, Qingfu
coredata.dc:description: Liquid electrolytes are prone to leaks and fires, which is exacerbated in Li metal batteries (LMBs) because of dendrite formation. Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) with their tunable mechanical properties and easy manufacturability, are increasingly becoming the preferred choice to address the interface issues in LMBs. However, their electrochemical instability against lithium-metal, mediocre conductivity and poorly interphases between Li and SPEs have prevented extensive application in LMBs. In this study, guided by theoretical calculations, an organic–inorganic composite solid-state polymer electrolyte (LPCU) based on Polyurethane (PU) and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) was designed, and showed no lithium dendrite penetration after 500 h of cycling. The addition of LLZTO makes up for the deficiency of lithium ion coordination environment in PU matrix and improve electrochemical performances of LPCU electrolytes. Owing to the room-temperature ionic conductivity of 2.22 × 10−4 S cm−1, the transference number of 0.55 and the improved contact interface of Li-SPE, the optimized LPCU with a LLZTO content of 4% could achieve 150.0 mAh/g with 90% retention capacity after 150 cycles at 1C rate and 60 °C for Li||LiFePO4 full batteries. This composite solid polymer electrolyte (LPCU) presents a powerful strategy for enabling the stable operation of LMBs.

Theoretical calculation
Safety
Lithium metal batteries

Thermal analysis and mechanical properties of PCU
DFT calculations and Molecular dynamic simulations

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: A) Li+ ion coordination structure investigation: A typical structure of the PCU. b) Comparison of the binding energy. c) The coordination environment of Li+ ion in PCU. d) Lithium-oxygen radial distribution functions in PCU.
a) The FTIR spectra of PCDL and PCU. b–d) DSC, TGA and Stress–strain curves of PCU.

Preparation mechanism and morphology characterization of LPCU electrolyte. a) The preparation schematic of LPCU electrolyte. b)–f) SEM image of LPCU0%, LPCU2%, LPCU4%, LPCU6% and LPCU8% electrolytes. g) The cross-section SEM image of LPCU4% electrolyte. h)–j) the corresponding EDS element mappings of La, Zr, and Ta in LPCU4% electrolyte.

a) Schematic diagram of a highly efficient battery interface with the addition of trace amounts of FEC. b) The ionic conductivity (σ) of LPCU0% electrolyte versus LiTFSI content at 30 °C. c) Arrhenius plots of all LPCU electrolytes based on measurements of ionic conductivity versus temperature (T). d) LSV for LPCU electrolytes. e) Initial and steady-state impedance diagram and polarization curve for LPCU4% electrolyte. f) The AC impedance for LPCU4% electrolyte at various storage times. g) Comparison of LPCU4% electrolyte with other reported polymer electrolytes. h) The cycling performance of the symmetric Li batteries with various electrolytes at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2.
SEM images of a) bare Li and b) Li-metal based on LPCU4% electrolyte after 500 h cycling at 0.5 mA cm−2. c) XPS spectra of the cycled Li-metal in Li/LPCU4%/Li battery.

a) Rate performance of Li/LPCU4%/LFP and Li/ LPCU0%/LFP batteries at 60 °C. b) Charge and discharge voltage profiles of Li/LPCU4%/LFP battery under different rates. c) Long-term cycling performance of Li/LPCU4%/LFP and Li/ LPCU0%/LFP batteries at 0.5C and 60 °C. d) Charge and discharge voltage profiles of Li/LPCU4%/LFP battery under different cycles. e) Long-term cycling performance of Li/LPCU4%/LFP battery at 1C and 60 °C. f) Long-term cycling performance of Li/LPCU4%/LFP battery at 0.2C and g) 0.5C with the temperature of 25 °C.

head.ce:title: Polyurethane/LLZTO solid electrolyte with excellent mechanical strength and electrochemical property for advanced lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Key Laboratory of Rubber-plastics, Ministry of Education, School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Polymer Science and Engineering
Qingdao University of Science and Technology

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Key Laboratory of Rubber-plastics, Ministry of Education, School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, Shandong, China

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Liquid electrolytes are prone to leaks and fires, which is exacerbated in Li metal batteries (LMBs) because of dendrite formation. Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) with their tunable mechanical properties and easy manufacturability, are increasingly becoming the preferred choice to address the interface issues in LMBs. However, their electrochemical instability against lithium-metal, mediocre conductivity and poorly interphases between Li and SPEs have prevented extensive application in LMBs. In this study, guided by theoretical calculations, an organic–inorganic composite solid-state polymer electrolyte (LPCU) based on Polyurethane (PU) and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) was designed, and showed no lithium dendrite penetration after 500 h of cycling. The addition of LLZTO makes up for the deficiency of lithium ion coordination environment in PU matrix and improve electrochemical performances of LPCU electrolytes. Owing to the room-temperature ionic conductivity of 2.22 × 10−4 S cm−1, the transference number of 0.55 and the improved contact interface of Li-SPE, the optimized LPCU with a LLZTO content of 4% could achieve 150.0 mAh/g with 90% retention capacity after 150 cycles at 1C rate and 60 °C for Li||LiFePO4 full batteries. This composite solid polymer electrolyte (LPCU) presents a powerful strategy for enabling the stable operation of LMBs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal (Li), which has ultrahigh theoretical capacity (3860 mAh g−1), the lowest redox potential (−3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) and a low weight (0.534 g cm−3), is considered the ultimate anode material in Lithium Metal Batteries (LMBs) [1–3]. Unfortunately, as LMBs include lithium dendrites, electrode expansion and flammable liquid electrolytes (LEs) which contain a large number of organic solvents, the security and stability issues become the factors that cannot be ignored for hindering their commercialization [4–6]. Thus, due to the comparatively good interface performance, electrochemical performance and flexible processing, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) have emerged as a promising candidate to replace separators and LEs in LMBs [7–10]. In the past few years, a variety of SPEs have been proposed including poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), polycarbonate (PC), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polymethacrylate (PMMA) and so on. However, the relatively low ionic conductivity at room temperature (RT) and poor resistance to lithium dendrites have become the main hindrances with the application of SPEs to LMBs [11–16]. Although above problems have been improved through numerous approaches, such as structural design of polymers, multiple polymer composite, the polymer in salt strategy and the introduction of inorganic and organic fillers, it is necessary to develop SPEs with high mechanical properties and room-temperature ionic conductivity for LMBs [17–19].

Polyurethane (PU), versatile and easy to synthesize, is highly engineered with different properties depending on raw materials and ratios. Owing to its mechanical strength, high flexibility and electrochemical stability, PU as SPEs has been reported [20]. It generally possesses a two-phase microstructure with soft segments and hard segments. The hard segments, which are made up of diisocyanates or polyisocyanates, through π–π interactions and hydrogen bonds, may maintain a strong mechanical and film-forming performance. Besides, the soft segments that are composed of long-chain diols can dissolve alkali metal salts and result in the improvement of ionic transportation. Because of this special structure, various types of polymer electrolytes based on PU such as Polyether PUs, Polycarbonate/Polyester PUs and Single-ion conducting PUs, have been explored extensively [21]. Among them, the polycarbonate-based PU electrolyte, especially when using Polycarbonatediol (PCDL) as the soft segment, exhibits a comprehensive performance that surpasses the other polyurethane-based electrolytes [21,22]. This is because the carbonate group ((-O-(C = O)-O-) in the polycarbonate diol has a high polarity and Li+ coordination oxygen, which is more conducive to the transport of lithium ions [22,23].

Bearing all of the above in mind, a Polyurethane Matrix Material (PCU) is synthesized, with PCDL as the soft segment and Isophorone diisocyanate (IPDI) as the hard segment. According to the Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Molecular Dynamics (MD) calculations, we found that PCU based on PCDL and IPDI have a low coordination binding energy to lithium ions, which facilitates lithium ion transport, but suffer from a lack of coordination environment for lithium ions in a slightly remote range [24,25]. To compensate for the absence of coordination environment of lithium ions in the PCU polymer matrix, the introduction of the garnet Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) as a fast ion conductor successfully enhances the ionic conductivity. Eventually, we design an organic–inorganic composite solid-state polymer electrolyte (LPCU) with a thickness of only 25 μm [26]. The LPCU electrolyte made through mixing PCU with LLZTO, and a cellulose film as the skeleton. In all samples, the LPCU4% electrolyte (containing 4 wt% LLZTO) has an ionic conductivity of 2.22 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C and an electrochemical stability window of 4.8 V. A LiFePO4/LPCU4%/Li battery must be assembled and its long cycle and rate performance must be evaluated, in order to achieve a high specific charge/discharge capacity and strong cycle stability. Upon cycling at 0.5C, the batteries with LPCU4% electrolytes demonstrate the ultra-high specific discharge capacities of 162 mAh/g, with a capacity retention of 99% after 100 cycles. It is encouraging to note that, even at room temperature, the batteries with LPCU4% electrolytes still achieve a specific discharge capacity of 113 mAh/g in the 1st cycle and a coulombic efficiency of 99% at 0.2C. This study not only investigates the Li+ pathway theory for PCDL-based PU electrolytes by using a theoretical calculation, but it also designs a composite solid electrolyte LPCU4% for the application of LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Theoretical calculation of the PCU matrix
ce:section.ce:para: We first calculated the coordination binding energy of Li-O in the PCU polymer matrix by DFT and clarify its possible Li-ion transport mechanism. Fig. 1 a shows the coordination structure of lithium ions and groups in the PCU, which are calculated by using the Gaussian program. A structural unit of the PCU is divided into different parts, according to whether the C = O bond is adjacent or not, in order to simplify the calculation [24,27]. As shown in Fig. 1a, CU1 including CU1(a)-Li+ and CU1(b)-Li+ are the non-adjacent structures of –NHCOO- and –OCO-, while CU2 including CU2(a)-Li+ and CU2(b)-Li+ are the adjacent structures of the two groups. When compared with the PEO, that the binding energy of 6 EO and Li+ reached 665.88 kJ mol−1, and the binding energies of CU and Li+ are 71.84, 64.70, 144.41 and 199.89 kJ mol−1, respectively, which demonstrates that lithium ions migrate more freely in the PCU (Fig. 1b). Moreover, the binding energies of both CU and Li+ structures are similar to each other, but the latter are relatively larger (144.41 and 199.89 kJ mol−1, respectively), which should be the main structure for Li+ transmission. The higher binding energy of EO and Li+ in the PEO means that it is more stable after forming a coordination structure, which is not conducive to the migration of lithium ions. On the contrary, the lower binding energies of the lithium ions and groups in the PCU are beneficial for the free lithium ions.

In addition, the coordination environment of the lithium ion in PCU matrix is equally important for Li+ transport rate. Fig. 1c shows the coordination environment of lithium ions and segments in the PCU, which are simulated by Molecular Dynamic (MD) simulations. The Materials Studio utilized the compass force field to minimize the energy of the system, with each simulation lasting 100 ns [28]. The simulation system consists of a polymer chain containing 50 repeating units and a Li-TFSI ion pair. To demonstrate the interaction between the segments in the PCU and the lithium ions, the Li-O Radial Distribution Function (RDF) was carried out. Fig. 1d shows that most of the Li ions exist in the vicinity of oxygen atoms with the distance of 0.2 nm to form a Li ion migration path. While the interatomic space of two adjacent oxygen is about 0.8 nm in PCU which might be too far for Li ion migration. Some of the missing oxygen atom positions in the region are greater than 0.8 nm, which inhibits the conduction of the lithium ions that migrate, to a certain extent, through their coordination with the O atoms. which inhibits the conduction of migrating lithium ions to some extent through the coordination with O atoms.

Therefore, providing more Li-ion binding sites in the PCU, to make up for its deficiency, might be able to improve its electrochemical performance. Therefore, the proper amount of the fast ion conductor LLZTO was utilized to enhance the lithium-ion transport capacity of the composite solid electrolyte further.

Fig. 2 a shows the infrared spectrum of PCDL and PCU. The original hydroxyl peak of PCDL at 3530 cm−1 is obviously weakened, and the stretching vibration peak of the amino NH bond appears at 3362 cm−1, which proves that the hydroxyl group is involved in the reaction. Moreover, the C-N bond-stretching vibration peak and the N-H bond-bending vibration peak appear at 1556 cm−1, combined with the C = O stretching vibration peak at 1740 cm−1, which indicates the formation of carbamate groups. The above key infrared data show that the preparation of the PCU is successful.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Thermal analysis and mechanical properties of PCU
ce:section.ce:para: The DSC curve of the PCU is shown in Fig. 2b, and it can be clearly seen that the glass-transition temperature (Tg) of PCU is −40 °C. As the Li+ in the polymer electrolytes are conducted through the movement of the chain segment, the PCU with a lower Tg will exhibit a better ionic conductivity and rate capability for SPE. The TGA curve of the PCU is shown in Fig. 2c. Clearly, the initial thermal degradation of the PCU begins at 300 °C, which is higher than the traditional TPUs, indicating its excellent heat resistance [29,30]. Thereafter, there is no obvious thermal decomposition step, mainly due to the simultaneous progress of the decomposition process of the soft and the hard segments. The superior thermal properties could ensure that the PCU maintains good stability when it is used as matrix material for SPE.

Their mechanical properties are one of the most vital factors for resisting lithium dendrites and improving the safety of LMBs. The stress–strain curve of the PCU is shown in Fig. 2d. It can be seen that it is a typical soft, yet tough, polymer material, and its mechanical strength reaches 14.6 MPa, which is much greater than that of the PEO with only about 2 MPa. This can greatly enhance the strength of the electrolyte membrane, so that it can effectively resist the formation of lithium dendrites and the volume change of the electrode. In addition, its elongation at the break can reach 460%, which due to the soft segments composed of linear polycarbonate glycol and proves its good flexibility.

As shown in Fig. 3 a, the composite solid electrolytes (LPCU) were fabricated by using a facile immersion approach. A certain quality of PCU and LiTFSI, and a different amount of LLZTO (2 wt%, 4 wt%, 6 wt%, 8 wt%) were dissolved in 100 mL DMF to form a homogenous and sticky solution. The cellulose membrane was immersed in the solution for a while and spread on a Teflon plate. Then, the composite solid electrolytes were dried at 85 °C for 24 h, followed by vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h. They were marked as LPCU2%, LPCU4%, LPCU6% and LPCU8% according to the LLZTO content. A control sample without LLZTO was made in the same way and named LPCU0%.

The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of LPCU membranes are displayed in Fig. 3. Fig. 3b–f are the SEM images of the LPCU0%, LPCU2%, LPCU4%, LPCU6% and LPCU8% membrane surfaces, respectively. When the surface of the LPCU0% solid electrolyte membrane is compared with the other LPCU membranes, different amounts and distributions of LLZTO were found. In particular, as the LLZTO content in the LPCU is 2% and 4%, the relatively uniform distribution exhibits no agglomeration phenomenon, demonstrate a better combination with the PCU material, which might aid ionic transport. Since the LLZTO content is 6% and 8%, large agglomerations and bumps can be formed on the surface of the composite membrane, which could have an adverse effect on the interface contact and the electrochemical performance. Therefore, because the LLZTO dispersion in the LPCU4% membrane is more extensive and uniform, Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images of the element distribution of La, Zr, and Ta is shown in Fig. 3h, i and j, which is crucial to guarantee the rapid Li+ transport. In addition, the cross-section morphology of the LPCU membrane is displayed in Fig. 3g. It can be clearly seen that the thickness of the composite film is about 25 μm and the PCU and LLZTO nanoparticles fill the pores of the cellulose film. This structure of LPCU membrane combines the advantages of the polymer matrix, nano-filler and backbone material, promising excellent mechanical and electrochemical properties.

The interface of solid-state batteries has been one of the thorny issues that prevented them from achieving high energy densities. Herein, small amounts of FEC (5 μL) were added in the battery assembly to improve the electrolyte–electrode interface [31,32] (Fig. 4 a). The relationship between the ionic conductivity and temperature plays a vital role in LMBs. We first determined the optimal addition amount of lithium salt LiTFSI in Fig. 4b. The ionic conductivity of the LPCU0% electrolyte showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing with the increase of LiTFSI content at 30 °C. The optimized concentration of LiTFSI was chosen to be 20 wt%. As can be seen in Fig. 4c, for all LPCU electrolytes, the plotting lgσ to 1000/T shows that the relationship between the ionic conductivity of the LPCU solid electrolytes and the temperature follows an Arrhenius behavior, which is consistent with literatures report [21]. In contrast to the LPCU0% electrolyte, the LPCU 2%-8% electrolytes showed less variation in conductivity with temperature, which may be related to the addition of LLZTO. The addition of LLZTO significantly improved the room temperature ionic conductivity of the LPCU 2%-8% electrolytes and confirms the superiority of the composite electrolyte designed according to theoretical calculations. Among them, the maximum ionic conductivity of the LPCU4% electrolyte with a LLZTO content of 4% is 2.22 × 10-4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, and 3.37 × 10-4 S cm−1 at 60 °C. Meanwhile, the activation energy data of the LPCU electrolytes are calculated in Table S1, and the LCPU4% electrolyte also has the smallest activation energy of 0.12 eV. If the LLZTO content continues to increase, the ionic conductivity drops instead. Combined with the SEM images of all the electrolyte membranes, this may be due to the fact that too many LLZTO nanoparticles agglomerated together, forming blocks on the surface and inside of the electrolyte membrane, which is not conducive to ion transport. Therefore, the addition of an appropriate LLZTO content in the LPCU4% electrolyte can effectively compensate the ionic conductivity resulting a synergistic effect. In such composite material, PCU guarantees the tenacious mechanical strength, good interfacial compatibility and suitable ionic conductivity.

The electrochemical stability is another crucial factor to evaluate the application for LMBs. The electrochemical stability curves of the LPCU solid electrolytes with a different LLZTO content were tested by using Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV). As shown in Fig. 4d, the electrochemical stability window of all the LPCU samples can reach 4.5 V (compared to Li+/Li) without obvious current fluctuation. The enlarged image in Fig. 4d is a partially-enlarged view of the electrochemical stability window at 4.6–5.0 V. Obviously, the electrochemical stability window of the LPCU4% solid electrolyte shows the highest value, and that it can reach 5.0 V. The electrochemical stability determines that the LPCU4% solid electrolyte can be applied to lithium iron phosphate cathodes and other high voltage cathode materials, which can meet the application requirements of LMBs.

Taking into account the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability window, the LPCU4% solid electrolyte is selected for further investigation. The solid electrolyte with the high lithium-ion transference number (t Li+) can achieve a uniform migration and deposition of Li+. Fig. 4e shows t Li+ test of the LPCU4% solid electrolyte using the steady-state current method. As shown in Fig. 4e, the initial impedance R0 and steady-state impedance Rs can be read as 255 Ω and 262 Ω, respectively. Similarly, the initial current I0 and steady-state current Is can be read as 3.31 × 10-2 mA and 2.88 × 10-2 mA. According to Eq. (1), it can be calculated that the t Li+ of the LPCU4% solid electrolyte is 0.55, which is slightly larger than the t Li+ (0.51) of the LPCU0% electrolyte (Fig. S1). In addition, Fig. 4g shows the detailed comparison of the LPCU4% solid electrolyte with many kinds of previously reported polymer electrolytes [22,33–41]. It is quite encouraging that the designed LPCU4% exhibits attractive comprehensive attributes in terms of room-temperature ionic conductivity, t Li+ and electrochemical stability window. In particular, the performance of the LPCU4% solid electrolyte is among the best reported for LMBs based on PU electrolytes.

The interfacial stability of Li/Li symmetric batteries based on LPCU4% solid electrolytes were tested by AC impedance spectroscopy, as well as potentiostatic polarisation methods, after different storage times. As shown in Fig. 4f, the initial interface impedance between the LPCU4% solid electrolyte and metallic lithium is 317 Ω and the impedance showed a gradually-increasing trend over time. After 9 days of storage, the interface impedance is stable at 362 Ω. This may be due to the creation of an interface strategy, so that the interface impedance does not increase sharply. The interfacial stability between SPEs and electrode is a vital requirement for LMBs. LPCU4% was used as the solid electrolyte to assemble the Li/LPCU4%/Li symmetrical battery to investigate the interfacial stability between lithium anode and LPCU4% via the potentiostatic polarization method. As shown in Fig. 4h, the Li/LPCU4%/Li battery presented a stabilized voltage during long-term galvanostatic cycling over 500 h at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2. The overpotential fluctuated at about 0.016 V in the first few hours, and then remained stable at about 0.026 V during the 500-hour cycle without a short circuit, showing a good interface stability. In a sharp contrast, the LPCU0% battery increased significantly over a period of 300 h (150th cycle) of operation and a local short-circuit after 450 h of cycling.

Comparing with the SEM image of bare Li in Fig. 5 a, the surface of Li anode based on Li/LPCU4%/Li battery shows relatively uniform lithium deposition and no lithium dendrites were detected in Fig. 5b. In contrast, the Li-metal anode of Li/LE/Li battery under the same conditions exhibits significant valley-like deposition with a large number of lithium dendrites (Fig. S2). As discussed above, electrochemically, the low overpotential and interface stability are attributed to the low Rct, high ionic conductivity, good transference number and mechanical properties of the LPCU4% that can inhibit the changes in lithium dendrites and electrode volume, thereby ensuring the smooth operation of the battery. The XPS can be used to further investigate the SEI composition on Li anode surface. As shown in Fig. 5c, The F 1 s profile exhibits a distinct LiF peak at 684.8 eV, which can be matched with previous reports in the literature [42]. And FEC has been demonstrated to contribute to the formation of LiF-rich SEI in organic liquid electrolytes, thereby improving the morphology and CE of Li anode. The enrichment of inorganic components especially LiF in the FEC-LPCU4%-derived SEI facilitates the formation of a compact and stable SEI. In the C 1 s spectra, the peaks assigned to C–C, C–O, and C = O mainly originate from the decomposition of the electrolyte. Furthermore, the Li 1 s profile also reveals the presence of LiF on the SEI surface. In summary, the addition of FEC contributed to the SEI formation of organic–inorganic components and the enrichment of LiF generated by FEC-LPCU4% can efficiently passivate the reactive surfaces and improve Li+ diffusion throughout the SEI.

The electrochemical performance of the LPCU electrolytes were evaluated in LMBs at 60 °C, using LiFePO4 as the cathodic material and Li metal as the anodic material. Fig. 6 a and b show the rate capability measurements of a Li/LPCU4%/LiFePO4 battery at different C-rates, which are cycled from 2.5 to 4.0 V. As shown in Fig. 5a, the discharge capacities of the battery with LPCU4% are 169, 168, 165, 162 and 148 mAh g−1 at various rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2C, generally higher than the battery-based LPCU0%. It is worth mentioning that the specific discharge capacity of the battery based on the LPCU4% is 169 mAh g−1 at 0.1C, which is already close to the theoretical value of the LFP cathode. In addition, even at a rate of 2C, the battery based on the LPCU4% still has a specific discharge capacity of 148 mAh g−1, and the coulombic efficiency is approaching 100%, demonstrate an excellent performance rate. In the process of gradually increasing the charge and discharge rates, the specific discharge capacity of the battery remained stable, which could be attributed to improving ionic conductivity of the LPCU4% and the stability with Li metal cathode. When the current returns from the high rate of 2C to the low rate of 0.2C, the battery capacity is 167 mAh g−1, essentially restoring to the initial 168 mAh g−1, indicating the high electrochemical stability of the LPCU4%. Furthermore, the long-cycle performance of battery based on LPCU4% electrolyte was evaluated under the same conditions. As shown in Fig. 6c, the solid-state battery with the LPCU4% electrolyte shows a substantially improved battery performance. At an elevated temperature (60 °C) and a cycling rate of 0.5C, the solid-state battery with the LPCU4% shows a 162.0 mAh g−1 initial capacity and an outstanding capacity retention of 99% at the 100th cycle, which is obviously higher than the solid-state battery with the LPCU0% electrolyte. Although the Coulombic efficiency of the first cycle was only 94%, the subsequent battery efficiencies all exceeded 99%, mainly due to the optimized ionic conductivity of the LPCU4% and good interfacial compatibility. Meanwhile, smooth charge–discharge curves of the 50th and 100th laps also show the good cycle stability of the battery by using the LPCU4% solid electrolyte (Fig. 6d). Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 6e, when the lithium battery using this solid electrolyte was tested at a higher rate of 1C, it also maintained a superior discharge specific capacity (150 mAh g−1), Coulomb efficiency (>99.5%) and capacity retention rate (above 90% after 150 cycles). Even comparing with previously reported solid-state LMBs, battery performances of Li/LPCU4%/LiFePO4 are still impressive (Table S2). The operation of electrolytes in the full battery is also an important evaluation index. Herein, the full batteries assembled with Li/NCM622 and Li/LiCoO2 also achieve 151 and 108 mAh/g discharge specific capacities at rates of 0. 2C and 0.5C, respectively (Fig. S3), which release the high performance of the resultant electrolytes. In terms of matching with the high voltage cathode, the battery performances of the LPCU4% electrolyte are also quite good compared to the PEO/LLZTO or PEO/LLZO composite electrolytes [43–46].

LMBs have a tough time achieving steady cycling and a higher discharge-specific capacity at room temperature, which is one of the factors preventing its commercialization. Therefore, we continue to evaluate the long-cycle performance of the solid-state battery based on the LPCU4% at 25 °C. As shown in Fig. 6f and g, the batteries equipped with the LPCU4% electrolyte exhibited 110 and 90 mAh g−1 initial capacity with stable CEs of ∼ 97% and ∼ 95%, over 100 cycles at C-rate of 0.2 and 0.5C, respectively. In the initial stages of the cycle, the discharge-specific capacity of the battery showed a slowly-increasing trend, and then gradually stabilized at a surprising value (140 and 98 mAh g−1 , respectively). This phenomenon can be attributed to the activation of the SPE by the Li ions at room temperature. In addition, the charge–discharge curves of the 1th, 50th and 100th laps also show the good cycle stability of the battery by using the LPCU4% solid electrolyte at 25 °C (Fig. S4). Firstly, this may be attributed to the excellent electrochemical performance of LPCU4% electrolyte design and the high ionic conductivity at room temperature, which enables the battery to achieve stable cycling. Secondly, this may be due to the addition of a trace amount of FEC to generate a LiF-rich SEI film during cycling, which stabilizes the electrode–electrolyte interface and facilitates the further release of the discharge-specific capacity of the battery.

In conclusion, we have elucidated the possible lithium ion transport mechanism and lithium ion coordination environment of the PCU solid electrolyte matrix based on PCDL and IPDI through theoretical calculations and successfully designed a composite solid electrolyte-LPCU with dramatic synergistic effect. The preferred electrolyte of the LPCU4% exhibits strong lithium dendrite resistance, low interfacial resistance, high the room-temperature ionic conductivity (2.22 × 10−4 S cm−1) and the transference number (0.55). The LMBs consisting of the LPCU4%, Li metal anode and LiFePO4 cathode, can deliver a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 (CE ∼ 99.5%) after 150 cycles at 1C rate at 60 °C. Furthermore, it still exhibits a capacity of 140 and 98 mAh g−1 (CE ∼ 99%) at 25 °C after 100 cycles at a rate of 0.2 and 0.5C, respectively. Through the design of composite solid polymer electrolytes and the modification of their interfacial compatibility, this hybrid design exhibits significant merits for LMBs, in terms of their overall energy density and cycling stability, which can also be extended to the operation of other post-metal batteries.

The PCDL (99%, Mn = 1000) and IPDI (99%, Aladdin) were added in a three-necked round-bottom flask (250 mL) equipped with a mechanical stirrer and thermometer under a nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction was carried out at 85 °C for 3 h. Afterwards, a quantity of Diethylene glycol (DEG, Aladdin) as a chain extender, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, Aladdin) as a solvent and Dibutyltin dilautrate (DBTDL, Aladdin) as a catalyst were quickly added into the reactor and they were stirred at 65 °C for another 3 h (Fig. S5). Subsequently, the PCU was obtained after 48 h of ageing in an 80 °C oven. The molecular weight of PCU was 142000 g/mol.

The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) of the PCU was tested by using a VERTEX 70 infrared spectrometer (Bruker, Germany), with an attenuated total reflectance mode in the range of 600–4000 cm−1. The thermal properties of PCU were measured with a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) (Model TA-Q20, TA Instruments, America) in the temperature range of −70 to 150 °C (nitrogen atmosphere). The Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was tested by using a Q50 thermal analysis instrument (TA Instruments, America), from room temperature to 600 °C, with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1. The tensile properties were examined with a stretching speed of 500 mm/min and a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM, JSM-7500F, Japan) was used to investigate the morphology of the LPCU membranes with an accelerating voltage of 3.0 kV.

ce:section.ce:section-title: DFT calculations and Molecular dynamic simulations
ce:section.ce:para: To illustrate the coordination of polymer-lithium ions, MD simulations were carried out in the Materials Studio. The Compass (Condensed-phase Optimized Molecular Potentials for Atomistic Simulation Studies) force field was used in the MD simulations to minimize the energy of the system, with each simulation lasting 100 ns. The atom-based summation method and the cubic spline truncation method were used for the electrostatic terms, with a cut-off distance of 15 Å, a spline width of 1 Å and a buffer width of 0.5 Å. In addition, the atomic summation method and the distant-corrected cubic spline truncation were used with a cut-off distance of 15 Å, a spline width of 1 Å, and a buffer width of 0.5 Å. One polymer chain with 50 repeating units was used in the simulation, when considering the polymer effect. Meanwhile, a single Li–TFSI pair was employed in each simulation. In order to show the interaction between the groups of polymers and ions, DFT calculations were performed on the Gaussian 09 program, by using the B3LYP/6–311 g (d, p) basis set [28,47].

The ionic conductivity(s) was tested by an AC impedance analysis, using a Bio-Logic VMP3 electrochemical station. The AC impedance measurements were measured on the LPCU electrolytes, which was placed between two spring-loaded, stainless-steel and plate-blocking electrodes, with the perturbation of 5 mV at a frequency of from 100 mHz to 1 MHz.

The electrochemical stability of the LPCU electrolyte was evaluated by using Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV). The battery of Li/LPCU/SS was conducted at a potential scanning rate of 5 mV s−1, and the Li ion transference numbers (t Li + ) were evaluated by using the method that was developed by Evants et al., who used a symmetric Li/LPCU/Li battery. The LPCU electrolytes were placed between two lithium metal electrodes at a frequency of between 100 mHz and 1 MHz, and the constant polarisation voltage for the DC polarisation test, which was set as 10 mV. t Li+, was calculated by using the following equation:

The coin cells (2032 type) were assembled by placing the LPCU electrolyte between the LiFePO4 cathode (LiFePO4/carbon black/PVDF, 80/10/10, w/w/w) and the lithium metal anode. The charge/discharge behavior or C-rate capabilities of the LiFePO4/Li, NCM622/Li and LiCoO2/Li batteries were examined by using a LAND battery test system (CT 2001 A, China) in a voltage range of 2.5 to 4.0 V.
